Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: MEMS Co-Steered Optical and Acoustic Dual Modal Communication and Ranging Devices for Underwater Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) are very important tools for many applications, including infrastructure inspection and maintenance, search and rescue, environmental monitoring, maritime archaeology, oil drilling and pipeline inspection, and defense. However, a significant and fundamental challenge faced by today?s AUVs is communication and perception in the underwater environment. Traditional devices are bulky and have low spatial resolution in ranging/mapping tasks. Acoustic communication is slow in speed. Laser-based communication can achieve high speed, but requires direct light of sight. Therefore, there is no effective way to tightly coordinate a group of AUVs.

The objective of this project is to develop a miniaturized dual-modal Microelectromechanical systems (MEMS)-based Sound Navigation And Ranging (sonar) and Light Detection And Ranging (LiDAR) combo device, named as oPtical and Acoustic communication and Ranging (PAIR) device. The PAIR device functions as both a dual band network adapter and a combination of sonar and LiDAR but with a much smaller footprint and better signal registration. Enabled by the use of a novel MEMS scanning mirror and ultrasound transducer
with unique mechanical and optical properties previously demonstrated, the PAIR devices can simultaneously transmit and receive both sound and laser signals in a co-centered and co-directional fashion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this research, a miniaturized oPtical and Acoustic communication and Ranging (PAIR) device has been investigated to simultaneously address the communication and perception challenge for teamed autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). The PAIR device functions as both a dual band network adapter and a combination of sonar (sound navigation ranging) and LiDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) but with a much smaller footprint and better signal registration. Enabled by the use of a novel water-immersible MEMS tilting mirror, a frontend module of the PAIR device has been developed to simultaneously transmit and receive both sound and laser signals in a co-centered and co-directional fashion. The co-centered and co-directional dual modal signals do not have synchronization or correspondence issues and can complement each other in both communication and ranging tasks, and therefore can enable the development of unique communication and perception capabilities with the PAIR device. With two frontend modules, an initial demonstration of searching, aiming and communication functions of the PAIR device has been conducted. Research findings from this project advance understandings in the emerging field of sensor fusion and networked robotics under real world constraints from the underwater environments.

Results obtained from this research have been published in journal articles, presented in conference talks, and also shown in out-reach activities. The research work and findings have improved the critical thinking, communication, problem-solving, technical writing, and teamed working skills of the graduate-student participants. This research will benefit a wide range of AUV applications such as oil platform inspection, nature conservation, environment protection, public safety, search & rescue, etc.
